metadata.sermon_title: Loving the Dreadful Day of Judgment
metadata.sermon_start_end: My family, like most families, loves to tell and retell certain stories. One of our most beloved stories concerns some favorite New England cousins, some years ago, whose daughter was to be married. She’d been raised as an Episcopalian and wanted the Episcopal service, but her grandfather, who was a [...] Therefore encourage one another and build one another up, just as you are doing,” and the power of the Ruler of the universe will be your strength and your shield, your rock and your fortress, your shepherd and your judge, your Savior and Redeemer, your Lord and your God. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's requirement of focusing on one specific pericope. It functions more as a thematic speech on 'Judgment' or 'Advent' using a mosaic of texts (1 Thess, Isaiah, 1 Peter, Matthew). It lacks the specificity of what can be found 'nowhere else' in a single passage.
quotes: Advent begins in the dark. Saint Paul writes... (I Thess. 5:1–3)
One of the classic readings for the season, a lament from Isaiah... (Isa. 64:5–7)
here is a place to listen carefully to the announcement of the first epistle of Peter (4:17)
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one primary text (e.g., 1 Thessalonians 5) and derive the sermon's movement exclusively from its unique logic rather than jumping between biblical 'exhibits'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is largely absent. There is no engagement with the Greek text or the specific historical-theological context of the Thessalonian or Petrine communities. The texts are used as proof-texts for the theme of judgment rather than being 'expounded'.
quotes: As a good many commentators have noted, the Advent season actually begins before the first Sunday of Advent.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the original context: why did Paul use the 'thief in the night' metaphor for this specific congregation? What was the 'misery' of the first readers?

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: This is the sermon's strongest point. The preacher demonstrates a broad knowledge of the humanities and current events (zeitgeist). The application to Zimbabwe, Afghanistan, and Abu Ghraib is concrete and avoids generalities.
quotes: Afghan girls, blinded and disfigured by an attack of acid sprayed in their faces
Stephen Lewis... is collecting testimonies from women who have survived politically motivated gang-rapes in Zimbabwe.
the Spanish desaparecidos, the people who wrote editorials... taken from their families under cover of darkness
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows from the specific text's unique point rather than from a general concept of 'impunity' vs 'judgment'.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is more of a thematic essay. While it moves between news and scripture, it does not 'expound' the hearer within the text. The text remains a commentary on the news, rather than the news being seen through the lens of a specific text's exposition.
quotes: I have never had any trouble finding Advent messages in the newspapers.
Exhibit number 2: a three-part article for Remembrance Day...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the 'exhibit' structure; allow the biblical narrative to set the pace and pull the contemporary examples into its own movement.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The category of 'misery' (judgment/impunity) is very strong. 'Redemption' is present but somewhat secondary to the ethical call. 'Gratitude' is framed as 'weapons of warfare' and deeds of kindness.
quotes: A culture of impunity is nothing less than hell.
God has not destined us for wrath, but to obtain salvation through our Lord Jesus Christ
any deed of kindness or generosity or courage... is a sign of the advent
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'redemption' aspect; ensure it is clearly 'outside of man' (extra nos) to prevent the sermon from becoming purely ethical/psychological.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon excels here according to Dekker's criteria. It takes the possibility of being 'lost' (temporal and eternal) seriously and explicitly challenges the 'culture of impunity' and the liberal rejection of judgment.
quotes: The preacher... announced that he would not preach on the Gospel that morning because 'we don’t believe in a God of judgment.'
do we want a world without the wrath of God?
The world will be purged of its iniquity in the consuming fire
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Connect the 'two ways' more strictly to the specific warning in 1 Thessalonians 5 (soberness vs. sleep).

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the cornerstone and the one who died, but the sermon's 'telos' often feels like 'justice' or 'the end of impunity' rather than Christ himself. Grace is present but slightly overshadowed by the thematic focus on wrath.
quotes: Christ Jesus himself being the cornerstone
the One who is and who was and who is to come, the Almighty
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make Christ more explicitly the 'telos' by showing how His person (two natures) is the only resolution to the tension between wrath and love.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 16.5 minutes (1650 words), the sermon falls short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum requirement. It lacks the 'breadth' required for true homiletic 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical portion (Thesis 2) to reach the 20-minute mark, providing more biblical 'breadth'.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is a strong thematic address that courageously tackles the 'two ways' and the reality of judgment, but it fails the formal definition of a sermon as 'exposition of a specific Bible passage'. It functions as a topical lecture on the necessity of divine wrath in a violent world, utilizing various scriptures as supporting evidence rather than allowing one pericope to lead. It is too short according to Dekker's standard and lacks rigorous exegetical grounding.
strengths: Strong emphasis on the 'Two Ways' and the seriousness of being lost/impunity.
Excellent contemporary application and awareness of the zeitgeist.
Effective use of 'Misery' as a category to challenge modern theological complacency.
weaknesses: Lack of a single, specific Bible passage as the foundation.
Insufficient length (under 20 minutes) to achieve necessary depth.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: According to Dekker’s strict formal criteria, this is not a sermon but a 'speech about a biblical idea' (Judgment). While substantively sharp, it lacks the formal discipline of scriptural exposition.
